answers.feedback_html: The pebble is in free fall so the initial velocity will be zero and the acceleration will be 9.80\,\text{m/s}^2\!. What will the velocity be after 2\,\text{s}?
Acceleration due to gravity is acting on the pebble for 2\,\text{s}. The starting velocity is zero, so the velocity after 2\,\text{s} will be the product of acceleration and time.
The formula v_f = v_0 + at will give the velocity with which the pebble strikes the water as 19.6\,\text{m/s}.
Use v_f = v_0 + at with v_0 = 0\,\text{m/s}, t = 2.00\,\text{s}, and a = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2\!.

stem_html: A girl drops a pebble from a high cliff into a lake far below. She sees the splash of the pebble hitting the water 2.00\,\text{s} later. How fast was the pebble going when it hit the water?

answers.content_html: Find the force acting on the body.
answers.feedback_html: In kinematic equations, we are interested in the effect of the force, not the force itself.

answers.content_html: Find the acceleration of a body.
answers.feedback_html: Finding the acceleration is not always necessary. We choose a suitable kinematic equation to solve for the unknown quantity.

answers.content_html: Find the initial velocity of a body.
answers.feedback_html: It is not always necessary to obtain the initial velocity.

answers.content_html: Find a suitable kinematic equation and then solve for the unknown quantity.
answers.feedback_html: After listing all of the known variables, the kinematic equations will help in determining the unknown quantities.

stem_html: Which of the following steps is always required to solve a kinematics problem?
